1_1H8x2Aeu28Lnj6vhXFNZ32kpvGS6dnqWGA.body:
I grew up during the "wild west" of the internet - No censorship, constant discoveries and new developments every day. ZeroNet feels like a resurgence of those times. 

Yes, it can feel dead and stagnant sometimes, but it's new. Many people have already pointed out the benefits of P2P web and over time it'll grow more popular. I believe the biggest surge of users will come from those who are looking for a new place to find torrentable content. 

We'll get there guys. In the meantime, just enjoy Internet 2.0.

> [grandpa](#comment_1_1DSiY7oNYWw4W5JZPQXwc5gk8YTA1sg8s8): What was the kind of content that kept you coming back?

ZeroNet content? The original draw towards ZeroNet for me was the fact that it was something new. P2P web is a great contender for Internet 2.0 and coming in at the ground floor to (hopefully) watch it grow is exciting. Unfortunately, due to having such a small user-base, this also means that it lacks fresh content. As more people discover it, it'll grow. The best part is no censorship and no central point of failure.

I probably spend around 80% of my time between ZeroTalk and 0List. Mostly lurking and reading unless I feel I have something I can contribute.

1_1CwbqLCD6TdkinNNNb4GneZxbsoJ6Mw6oE.body:
The instructions need a little clarity and fine tuning for novice users, but everything here looks legit. Thanks 12hlearn -  It's a great guide on how to run ZeroNet off a USB drive attached directly to your router (if your router supports it).

Having said that, I'd suggest running ZeroNet on a stand-alone device instead. A Raspberry Pi would be much more suitable, or even an old PC you have lying around - Chuck your preferred flavor of Linux on there, setup your VPN, then chuck it in the corner and let it seed away. This way you have a little more control over Bandwidth and traffic allowances (for those people that still have to operate within peak/off-peak times).

2_1PTaJe3LLeB5Pfxq8KjcpQSPcSK1PQqsQs.body:
Because ZeroNet is currently one of the only real platforms out there for free speech. You can say whatever you want without being censored. But having free speech doesn't mean you're not free from criticism. For every comment like whitethunder's below, there's someone calling him out on his racism. 

I don't agree with anyone's racist comments, but I'll defend their right to say them until the day I die. There is no such thing as a safe space except the one you create in your mind. If you don't like what someone has to say, simply ignore it.

This shit has been going on for so long and people still don't grasp that concept.

> [00d4n1](#comment_17_1Mr36Z4TSbWQ236NfvRPeLn3qsAwngBzMd): Deleting whitethunder's comment since it's disgustingly racist isn't a violation of free speech. You can stand for freedom of speech without supporting that shit. https://xkcd.com/1357/

That's all well and good when you're talking about free speech within a country like the United States - Which the xkcd comic is actually referring to. The internet is a different monster altogether. It's not owned by a country or regulated (at least it shouldn't be). 

Racists have the same right to comment their bullshit just as much as anyone else. It doesn't matter if you're a feminist, brony, transgendered, white male, muslim, chinese, straight female, midget, giant or an obese asexual that identifies as a 1950' era fridge. Everyone should have the freedom to say what they want on a completely free platform such as the internet. If all racist comments are censored, who's to say all anti-government comments won't be next? Followed by anti-celebrity comments. Followed by anti-Futurama comments. 

It's a slippery slope and the notion of censorship on the internet should never be entertained. If you support the censorship of shit you dislike and choose to wrap yourself in a little bubble of "safety", no one will be there to help you when the things you DO like are censored.

I mean really, is it THAT hard to ignore someone? Has society come to the point where we're all so easily offended that we'd rather hand over our rights just to have the illusion of safety?

> [00d4n1](#comment_20_1Mr36Z4TSbWQ236NfvRPeLn3qsAwngBzMd): The xkcd comic is referring to the only concept of free speech that exists - which is that the government can't arrest you for what you say.

Yet the very definition of freedom of speech specifically refers to censorship: "Freedom of speech is the right to articulate one's opinions and ideas without fear of government retaliation or censorship, or societal sanction." 

> [np](#comment_2_1Hr2EnaPQkPexyHaMMaVNNHbSwjMezoQWD): 
> Yes it is. This is why forums need sections, to separate people who want to ignore each other. Temporarily or permanently. This is why it can't be censorship to block someone from a community or to filter content out of sections.
> If that where the case, then you are censoring someone by preventing them from sending you spam or by using an add blocker. A simple case of subscribing to a single publisher is also censorship of all other publishers. 
> Why do you do all those things? Because ignoring, is extremely hard. It's not only a hard problem, its a unsolvable problem without what most call censorship.
> This inst about safety, this is about the fact that i would much rather be reading about other things then waste of times, like politics and religion. That requires some system that allows filtration of content. Which in turn is called censorship.

I read through that and was confused until I realized we're both talking about two completely different types of censorship.

I'm all for the block button. Being able to personally block a user's content from appearing when you view a website? Yes please. It's the equivalent of putting your headphones in when someone says something rude in real life. Sign me up. 

What I am against however, is completely banning/filtering a user or topic just because a certain percentage of the population doesn't want to hear it. That's the difference here. Like I said previously, I don't agree with the garbage being posted, but where do you draw the line? You have to have all of it, the good and the bad. If you choose to surround yourself with people that think and conform to the same ideas as you, you'll be forever living in an echo chamber and will never have your opinions challenged.

> [mynameislegion](#comment_28_1NAaF8VitwKSPo79RzJFhqz14gndmdWcGV):
> if you want to discuss Jews, please start your own site and discuss the purity of your genes there. 
> If you want to contribute to ZeroNet in other ways than spreading your ideology like the witnesses of Jehova, you are welcome to participate on the main page.

"You can talk about any cult or ideology except for the ones I don't agree with" - I know people that have escaped the cult of Jehova. It's a scam that preys on people that have recently lost loved ones. They steal money and possessions from their members to ensure those at the top of the food chain are kept in a luxurious lifestyle.

Yet I'd welcome anyone who's a Jehova to come and post about it here. They have every right to, just as everyone else has the right to disagree. You can't pick and chose what is off-limits and what isn't, as what's offensive to you might be a way of live for me and vice versa. 

If you grew up in a racist household and all your friends were racist, that'd be the only life you'd know. You'd post your rubbish on an internet forum and people would call you out. Without that, these people will never be challenged to think differently or learn how to form outside opinions. Sure you might not want to deal with it or sift through all the bullshit, but a personal block button would remedy that - Outright banning them or preventing discussions on certain topics is not the way for ZeroNet to move forward. 

We don't want another Reddit...

> [00d4n1](#comment_21_1Mr36Z4TSbWQ236NfvRPeLn3qsAwngBzMd): Notice how it says "government retaliation or censorship"? The modifier "government" applies to both of those words.

I guess I (and the rest of the free world) interpret it as two completely separate statements: "Government retaliation" and "censorship" - not "Government censorship".

Regardless, both the European and American Convention on Human Rights state that everyone has:

1. the right to seek information and ideas;
2. the right to receive information and ideas;
3. the right to impart information and ideas

It doesn't say "information and ideas, unless it hurts people's feelings". If that isn't enough, it goes on to specifically say:

"International, regional and national standards also recognize that freedom of speech, as the freedom of expression, includes any medium, be it orally, in written, in print, THROUGH THE INTERNET or through art forms. This means that the protection of freedom of speech as a right includes not only the content, but also the means of expression."

This honestly isn't a hard concept to grasp...

1_1NTgaYjK2bh1axvruth8HqtGt6Pw5ab13x.body:
On the ZeroNet launch page, underneath "Hello ZeroNet_",  you'll see two headings - "Sites" & "Files".

"Sites" will list all the .bit sites (or zites) you view and are potentially seeding. Simply click the 3 dots that appear to the right of the site name and select "Delete". This will delete the entire local copy of the site from your PC and you'll no longer seed it until the next time you view it.

The "Files" header will show all files and optional files of any site that you've decided to seed. If you want to keep seeding a site except one or two of the files, simply select/tick the files you want to remove and click the "delete" button.

1_16bYoVV4ZHBY4kA416cTDvU1ZpjcLNkavi.body:
Cheap, easy and reliable - https://www.privateinternetaccess.com/ - It'll work on any platform and they claim they don't keep logs, so even if they get subpoenaed by the Government, there's nothing to hand over. Whether this is true or not is questionable, but there's been no proof so far that they log.

If you have some IT knowledge (or know someone that does), the best option is to create your own VPN. Purchase a cheap VPS (Virtual Private Server) and configure your own VPN and run all traffic through that. The downside is that a VPS will be more expensive, but if you get a few people together and all chip in, you can all use it at a reduced cost.

> [ghostaz](#comment_3_17jhcV7ACnYLDiBSdw6KqL3d9WVjDtcjf1): Hello friend, cool article, really liked! Tell me where to get this server (VPS)?And do you know where you can buy a jabber server? Thank

There's loads of places that will sell you hosting space. Do a search for "Cheap VPS Hosting" and you'll get too many hits to comb through - Some as cheap as $2-3 a month. I'd give you some recommendations, but I'm not sure what part of the world you're located in. I say that because it'd be advisable to purchase a VPS nearby - Whether it's in your own country or a neighboring one.

If you want to test it out and see if you can build your own VPN before committing to hosting costs, sign up for Amazon's AWS service. Their lowest tier hosting is free!

14_1KdnTJVBGzEZrJppFZtzfG9chukuMv8xSb.body:
> [seequ](#comment_3_19BZ9s633TaM3t7oW5bQPTPQJU3cbyibVH): Maybe. Anyways, easier auditing would be useful.

Not maybe, Kaffie is straight-up correct. Opt-in seeding would kill ZeroNet.

I understand your concern though. Until a proper counter measure can be created the best option you have is to run everything through a trusted VPN and TOR - That way if you end up seeding something sinister you won't be caught. No, it isn't fool proof, but this is the wild west of Internet 2.0 and you need to understand that there will be road bumps and issues along the way.

4_1NTgaYjK2bh1axvruth8HqtGt6Pw5ab13x.body:

Ding, ding, ding! We have a winner!

Facebook is so ingrained that it's become a part of everyones lives. They could come out and say "We sell all your data to the Russians" and people would still use it. There's a small percentage of people that quit and actually stay gone, but for everyone else the convenience of having all their friends in one place is too good to give up - Even if they're aware of Facebook's shady business practices.

The most common phrase I hear on an almost daily basis is "I've got nothing to hide". It's such an ignorant and narrow-minded statement, they may as well say "I'm happy being cattle, let me live in my safe space".
